text.headline: The 'Hood
text.text:
I came home from school with my nose pounded sideways and eyes swollen blurry from crying and taking fists to the face. There was dirt in my hair, tooth grit crunching in my mouth and my fingers were so numb I couldn’t work the key into the lock. One of our neighbors had to let me in the building.

“Six B? You’re in six B, right?” I nodded, jiggled the latch, blubbered something incoherent through the balled up shirt I was using to mop my blood mustache. “Hold on, I’m a-comin’,” he said, pulling one of those two wheel pull carts through the lobby like it were an old dog. “Say now — what happened to you? You fall or somethin’?” I was probably twelve at the time, I guess. Mom’s latest boyfriend, Jack, had moved us in with him over the weekend. His apartment wasn’t so far from our old place that I had to start a new school, but it was in a different neighborhood, the rough Western Addition; I was the new kid all the same. I didn’t know anybody on my block and the beat down I’d just suffered behind the row of Section 8’s between home and school was a bitter introduction to my new zip code.

A look at the US during this first Census data collection.

Map (left) is an example of a URL to an image hosted on the web.
